bibl.title: Memorandum from [Paul L. Tate] to Albert E. Truby, [June 1953]

div1.p: [Tate] discusses the confusion of several names. He thinks that the man listed as Jose Martinez was really Jose M. Fernandez.

div1.head: Memorandum from [Paul L. Tate] to Albert E. Truby, [June 1953]
div1.p:
I decided to write and send you this with
my letter.

I became interested in that mix-up of Spanish names at Camp
Lazear. I saw the real names long ago and since then wondered
where the name Martinez came from. Of course, it does not
matter at this late date, and does not affect your cost-sheet
figures, but I was curious to learn how it happened.

You see, no one has produced factual evidence of any kind that
there was a man named Martinez there. I don't consider Senate
Document of 1911 accurate on all proints.

I look at my photostat of S. & W. (List of Patients) and see
there two named Fernandez. I cannot imagine any Army clerk,
(and looking at it I see he was an efficient one, probably
Moran) carrying two men of identical last names on a record
for three months unless it was correct. If I was that clerk
it could not have happened, and from this paper, he was a
better one than I was.

Then, Doctor Ames saw this report frequently and when it was
completed it was officialy signed by him. He and that clerk
would have know for certain about those names and what ex-
periments they took.

Then, I cannot think of Major Reed authorizing checks to two
men both named Fernandez, and Major Kean so making them out
unless it was correct. If there was any reason to change a
check, he would have issued a new one and marked one stub as
void, which, evidently, was not done.

So, I got Lambert's new address and wrote to him, the only
man alive today who could know anything about it first-hand,
simply asking him if a man named Martinez had been treated by
him and had there been more than one Fernandez. I did not tell
him why I wished to know.

He replied as follows, Quote: “Nicines Fernandez was 4th case,
and Jose M. (for Martinez) Fernandez was 6th case. His friends
always called him by his middle name--Martinez--and I did the
same so as not to get them or the records mixed. I have seen
many writings where Martinez was used as his last name. If you
asked Mrs. Jernegan whose blood her husband took, she would
say, “Martinez,” because that is the only name Jernegan and
others knew him by, but his last name was Fernandez, same as
Nicines was.”

Only thing wrong with that is that the initial of the 6th case
on the Epidemic Report for the Surg. Gens. Office was not an
M, but an N! And I would not think cases would be mixed on
the record, as Lambert says, for Nicomar was entered as cured
just one day after Jose entered, but he may have been held in
hospital. Dr. Ames held some Spanish cases over to cheer up
their friends. But despite this inaccuracy, I do not think
that any man bearing the last name of Martinez was ever treated
there--Too much evidence against it. Of course, all this don't
amount to anything serious anyway, but it amuses me to track
it down, and it may give you some different ideas.

There $50 check to Martinez was evidently endorsed by him that way.
There checks were cashed & money turned out to them.
